newsitem.title: USA: Clinton sets budget that reaches surplus in 2002.
newsitem.headline: Clinton sets budget that reaches surplus in 2002.

text.p: President Bill Clinton on Thursday presented a $1.69 trillion budget that would cut $98.4 billion in taxes over five years, raise $76 billion in various taxes and fees, yet still reaches balance by 2002.

The fiscal 1998 budget, which covers the year beginning on Oct. 1, was formally released on Thursday after being widely leaked Wednesday. It forecast a 1998 deficit of $120.6 billion against 1997's $125.6 billion, gradually shrinking over the next three years and becoming a $17 billion surplus in 2002.

The budget forecast steady economic growth of 2.0 percent for 1997 and 1998, rising to 2.3 percent from 1999 through 2002. It would increase revenues by a mix of closing corporate tax loopholes, restoring some expired excise taxes and selling $36.1 billion worth of broadcast spectrum over five years.
As previously reported, the budget would trim $100 billion over five years from projected spending on the popular, and politically sensitive, Medicare health care programme for the elderly.

In putting forward the proposal, Clinton, a Democrat, was essentially presenting his opening offer in the annual budget negotiations between the president and Congress. Republicans hold a majority in both the Senate and House of Representatives.

In a message accompanying the budget, Clinton noted that the budget deficit has been cut by more than 60 percent since he took office in 1993. "I want to work with Congress to achieve the final increment of deficit cutting and bring the budget into balance for the first time since 1969," he added.
